title: System requirements - AppHub
content:
This section gives information about the required infrastructure and software with their supported versions.

Kubernetes distributions

The following Kubernetes distributions are supported in this release:

  • Embedded Kubernetes packaged with OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT).
  • Amazon Elastic Kubernetes v 1.23, 1.24, 1.25. See Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) documentation.
  • Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) v 1.23, 1.24, 1.25. See Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) documentation.
  • Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform v 4.10, 4.11, 4.12. See Red Hat OpenShift documentation. OpenShift Container Platform deployment on managed cloud platforms isn't supported.

Container image registry

Kubernetes cluster needs access to a registry where the container images are located. You can set up any image registry that's Docker Registry HTTP API V2 compliant. For example, Elastic Container Registry for AWS.

The images are published on Docker Hub.

Make sure you have the required access to upload the OO Containerized container images. You require the following information to upload the images to the registry:

  • Registry URL
  • Image pull secrets. For more information, see Image pull secrets in Kubernetes documentation.
If you are using OMT, the registry is available as part of the OMT installation. You also don't need to give the access requirements.

The container images are downloaded:

  • during install and upgrade
  • anytime the cluster goes down or a pod goes down
  • if any image is missing in the cluster

If you need to download the images from Docker Hub, they will use plenty of network resources every time the images are pulled. To prevent this, it's recommended to use a private image repository, so that this traffic stays within your network. A better choice would be to download images once to the cluster and let the cluster handle any image requests.

You may need to do one of the following to download and upload installation images:

  • Download OMT and application images from Docker Hub to a private image repository server in a customer network. Use this private image repository server to download the images during OMT and application installation as required and thus serves as a “cache” for all users in that network.
  • Download OMT and application images from Docker Hub to a private machine in your network:
    • Download OMT and application images directly from Docker Hub to a local machine using the download images script provided by OMT.
    • Upload these images to the embedded Kubernetes cluster using the upload images script provided by OMT.
  • Download OMT and application images from Docker Hub to a local machine (localhost:5000) using scripts provided by OMT. The images are stored within the cluster.

Databases

OO Containerized supports the following external database:

Relational database

PostgreSQL v 13.x, 14.x, 15.x, 16.x (Amazon RDS supported for AWS)

The following table shows the parameter values based on the OO Containerized deployment size. Configure the following parameters in <PGDATA_PATH>/postgresql.conf file. In AWS RDS, configure the parameters through RDS Parameter Groups and Values.

Storage

Provisioning the required storage for the application depends on the Kubernetes provider. Configure the required storage and additional disks on all worker nodes to persist data across containers when they're started or stopped, and for shared data access between containers. 

Embedded Kubernetes

Storage selector Default storage class name Storage type Access mode Description Required by capability
default-rwx <empty> File storage RWX Filestore storage, with general purpose performance requirements shared between multiple replicas of the pods or between different pods. Usually implemented through an NFS server.

Certified NFS types:
  • Linux based NFS
  • HPE 3PAR File Persona
  • Hitachi's NAS platform

OO Containerized

AWS

Storage selector Default storage class name Storage type Access mode Description Required by capability
default-rwx cdf-default File storage RWX

Available through Amazon Elastic File System (EFS). Make sure you configure Amazon EFS  with two private subnets, Amazon EFS performance mode as General Purpose and throughput mode as Bursting Throughput.

You can enable data encryption. To do this, you must use an encrypted EFS and deploy the EFS Container Storage Interface.

OO Containerized

Red Hat OpenShift

You can choose to use either NFS or Ceph File System (CephFS).

Storage selector Default storage class name Storage type Access mode Description Required by capability
default-rwx ocs-storagecluster-cephfs File storage RWX Filestore storage, with general purpose performance requirements shared between multiple replicas of the pods or between different pods. Implement this through an NFS server or through the OpenShift Data Foundation (ODF).

Certified NFS types: Linux based NFS, HPE 3PAR File Persona, and Hitachi's NAS platform

Ceph File System (CephFS):

To set up OpenShift Data Foundation on an OpenShift Container Platform with worker nodes on a Red Hat Enterprise Linux, you must install Local Operator and OpenShift Data Foundation Operator. See Product Documentation for Red Hat OpenShift Container Storage for details.

You can set up the OpenShift Data Foundation (ODF) either internally, within the OpenShift cluster, or externally.
When using OpenShift Data Foundation as storage, there is no need to create persistent volumes. During deployment, OpenShift Data Foundation will automatically create the required persistent volumes, based on the storage class provided as input.

OO Containerized

If you use dynamic volume provisioning to create the volumes on demand, make sure that your provisioner is able to give the storage with access mode ReadWriteOnce and ReadWriteMany. For more information on the access modes refer to the Kubernetes documentation.

UID and GID

OO Containerized requires a specific user and group to be created and associated with the User Identifier (UID) and Group Identifier (GID) which has a default value of 1999. If 1999 is unavailable, you can set the UID and GID to any value from 100000 to 2000000000.

For application installation, the UID and GID must map to the value given during OMT installation.

When deploying on Red Hat OpenShift, the values for the UID and GID need to be retrieved from the Kubernetes namespace.

Software requirements

Operating systems

Embedded Kubernetes

For details on the operating systems supported for embedded Kubernetes, see Embedded Kubernetes requirements section in OMT System requirements.

External Kubernetes

For information on operating system versions supported for external Kubernetes listed in the Kubernetes distributions section, see the related Kubernetes documentation.

Browsers

  • Mozilla Firefox 106 or later
  • Google Chrome 107 or later
  • Apple Safari 16.1 or later
  • Microsoft Edge 107 or later

Screen resolution

1280 × 1024 (minimum screen resolution required)

Languages

The following languages are supported by OO Containerized UI:

Network requirements

The recommended network latency between the Kubernetes cluster nodes is one millisecond (1 ms) or less for best performance and stability.

Network identification

The application doesn't require an HA virtual IP if you have a single master deployment. The FQDN of the master (control plane) node acts as the external access host.

Communication connection on cloud

Application install uses an external access host for some services. As a prerequisite, you must make sure to allow an L3 Bidirectional connection between the remote system and AWS setup to access application services. You can do this using a VPN connection or Direct Connect. If L3 communication isn't enabled between the remote system and AWS setup, you must create an environment in the same VPC to access application services. You must set up a private DNS zone.

You can either create a private domain or use an existing private domain in Register domain. For steps to create a private domain, see the AWS documentation. You will use this record name for the external access host configuration.

You can either create a self-signed certificate or use an existing certificate. In the AWS Management Console, search and click Certificate Manager. Import the certificate for the external access host. Once you upload the certificate, it will appear as imported in the AWS Certificate manager tab. You will give this certificate details for the serverCrt and serverKey parameters when configuring the load balancer for OMT and application.

Required port

Services deployed by OO Containerized can be exposed outside the Kubernetes cluster over a node port or a load balancer.

Make sure that this port is available before you deploy the application in case you are deploying with service type Node Port. This is the default port. You can configure this port to a different value in case the one listed is in use.

Default Port Protocol Service Description Required for capability
9443 HTTPS OO Containerized Ingress Controller External Access Port for the OO Containerized deployment OO Containerized
